headline: Owls End the Night with Victory Over Charleston in Field of 68
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's men's basketball team opened up the Field of 68 Tip-Off with a wire-to-wire 94-77 victory over Charleston on Saturday evening at Liberty Arena. The Owls (2-0) jumped out to a double-digit lead over the Cougars (1-2) early and did not look back the rest of the way. In a typical balanced offensive showing under Head Coach John Jakus, six players scored in double figures, with all 13 who stepped onto the court recording points. FIRST HALF Like the previous game, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool opened scoring. Five straight points from redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams gave the Owls an early 12-3 lead, with a dunk from junior center Vincent Neugebauer putting the team ahead by double digits. The lead grew to as big as 19, with a late shot from junior guard Kanaan Carlyle sending the Owls to the locker room with a 48-32 advantage. Defensively, Florida Atlantic did not surrender a field goal to four Charleston starters, holding them to a combined 0-for-11 shooting. SECOND HALF Two triples from junior forward Xander Pintelon put Florida Atlantic up by 20 five minutes in the second half. The Owls then worked their way in the paint, with sophomore Maxim Logue connecting on four shots in a four-minute span. Florida Atlantic led by as much as 25 and reached the 90-point mark with a three-pointer from redshirt freshman Liam Dayco-Green in his collegiate debut. PRESS CONFERENCES STATS & NOTES The Owls made the most of their second chance opportunities, outscoring the Cougars 24-7. Florida Atlantic converted 11 shots behind the arc, their second straight game with 10+ to open the season. Carlyle led the team in scoring for the second game in a row, this time with 14. Logue shot a perfect six-for-six from the field. Vanterpool had another balanced statline, logging six rebounds and five assists. Three Owls recorded the first points of their collegiate careers: Neugebauer, redshirt freshman guards Amar Amkou, and Dayco-Green FAU holds a 4-1 record in the Field of 68 Tip-Off. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will close the Field of 68 Tip-Off, facing host team Liberty on Sunday, Nov. 9. Tipoff is at 6 p.m. on the Field of 68's YouTube channel. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Jackson‚Äôs Buzzer-Beater Seals Road Win at Kennesaw State
content: KENNESAW, Ga. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team moves to 2-0 on the season, notching Coach Freeland's first road win at Florida Atlantic with a 69-68 victory over Kennesaw State on Saturday at VyStar Arena. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls trailed for much of the first quarter before Michiyah Simmons tied it at 10 with 4:33 left to go in the first. The game began to pick up speed, going back and forth, ending the first quarter with Florida Atlantic leading 19-16 off a Destyne Jackson 3-pointer. FAU started the second quarter strong, extending their lead to 26-19 in the first two minutes. Kennesaw State cut the Florida Atlantic lead to three at 29-26 by the media timeout. Jackson put the Owls' lead back to six with 30 seconds remaining in the half. The Owls entered halftime with a 37-31 lead. To start the third quarter, Kennesaw State committed three team fouls, and the Owls' lead extended to 10, 41-31, within the first minute of play. KSU began to close the lead before a Grace Carstensen 3-pointer extended the lead back to seven. The Owls then gained their largest lead of the contest at the six-minute mark with the score standing at 51-40. FAU held its lead at nine through the end of the third, taking a 61-52 lead into the final 10 minutes of play. Kennesaw State made a run in the fourth quarter, keeping Florida Atlantic from scoring for over two minutes. The Owls' lead shrank to one point, sitting at 64-63 with 3:48 to go in the game. KSU took the lead with two minutes to go in the game before Jackson called game with a corner 3-pointer with two seconds left to capture the win, 69-68. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I thought we played really well for the first three quarters, and then the fatigue set in a little bit, but I'm extremely proud of the fight and the grit to finish the game. Destyne's shot at the end of the fourth was huge. Just really proud of our team effort and our belief that we would pull it out." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Four Florida Atlantic players finished in double figures. Jackson with 13, Simmons with 12, Jess Moors with 11, and Carstensen with 10. Vivian Onugha led the team in rebounds on the night with four. Simmons had a team-leading five assists. The Owls were 50 percent from both field goal and 3-point range on the night, matching up well to Kennesaw State's 48.1 field goal percentage and 16.7 three-point percentage. UP NEXT The Owls head to Coral Gables to face Miami on Thursday, Nov. 13, at 7 p.m. inside the Watsco Center on ACC Network Extra. FOLLOW THE OWLS For updates, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Drop Three-Setter at Rice
content: HOUSTON ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic Volleyball battled tough against conference leader Rice, but the Owls fell in three sets, 3-0 (25-20, 25-19, 26-24), on the road Sunday in Houston. The Owls fall to 17-10 overall and 8-6 in American play, while Rice moves to 17-8 on the season and 13-1 in league play. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls took the early lead 2-0, scoring back-to-back points off a kill from Anna Hartman and a Rice attacking error. Florida Atlantic maintained an advantage through a 10-9 lead after a Rice service error, however, Rice produced a 5-1 run to take its first lead of the set, 14-11. FAU scored three unanswered points off a pair of kills from Olivia Hart and Kayla Richardson, as well as a hitting error, but Rice retook the lead 15-14 at the first set media timeout. Out of the break, another Rice service error and a kill from Hart put the Owls back in front, 16-15. However, a 5-0 Rice run shifted the lead once again, 20-16, forcing a pair of timeouts from the Owls. Rice closed the set on a 5-4 run to take the opening 1-0 lead. After battling through a 9-9 stalemate to open set two, Rice scored nine unanswered points to break away to an 18-9 advantage. The Owls battled back, producing a 5-1 run to cut the deficit to five, 19-14, forcing Rice to call its first timeout of set two. However, the Owls couldn't muster another run as they traded points throughout the remainder of the set, as Rice eventually took the second set 25-19 for the two-set lead. FAU took the lead to open set three, holding an 11-9 advantage after a kill from Hartman and a block from Kierstin Bevelle and Libby Ashline. Rice retook the lead 14-12 after a 5-1 run, but FAU responded to take the lead back, eventually holding a 23-21 advantage. The Owls held set point at 24-23, but a service error and two attacking errors closed out the match as Rice took the set 26-24 to claim the three-set match. STATS & NOTES Hart and Hartman paced the Owls in the match, recording 11 and 10 kills, respectively. Emsley Venard dished out a team-high 17 assists across the three sets. Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, recording a team-high 12 digs. Bevelle paced the Owls' block, tallying a team-best three blocks in the match. UP NEXT The Owls return home next week, hosting South Florida on Wednesday, Nov. 12, before closing the regular season against UTSA on Friday, Nov. 14, for Senior Day. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Defeated by Flames to Split Field of 68 Tip-Off
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team dropped the 2025 Field of 68 Tip-Off finale to Liberty by a score of 88-68 on Sunday evening. While the Flames (3-0) handed the Owls (2-1) their first loss of the season, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool impressed with a career high 24-point performance, shooting 10-for-15 from the field. FIRST HALF For the third game in a row, Vanterpool converted the first field goal make for the Owls for his first two of 10 points in the opening period. FAU kept the game within single digits for the first 12 minutes before surrendering a three-pointer to fall behind 31-19. Continuing to find success off offensive rebounds, Florida Atlantic outscored Liberty 13-2 on second chance points in the first half. The Owls closed a 20-point deficit with a 9-2 run before entering the locker room at halftime trailing 48-30. SECOND HALF Vanterpool continued where he left off with a three-pointer to open second-half scoring. He scored eight of the Owls' first nine points, including a three-point play. Junior guard Kanaan Carlyle attacked the hoop with all eight of his points coming in the final 20 minutes. PRESS CONFERENCE STATS & NOTES Vanterpool's 24 points doubles his previous career high of 12. Sophomore forward Maxim Logue made three out of his four field goal attempts. He finished the Field of 68 Tip-Off, shooting a combined nine-for-10 from the field. Redshirt freshman guard Amar Amkou scored a career-best eight points in six minutes of action. Florida Atlantic won the rebounding battle 34-28. The Owls outscored the Flames 11-2 on fastbreak points. UP NEXT The Owls will have a week off before returning to Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Monday, Nov. 17, for a meeting with Coastal Georgia. Tipoff is at 7 p.m. on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Owls Advance to American Conference Championship
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer (11-3-2) knocked off Tulsa (5-9-4) by a 3-0 final on Wednesday in the American Conference Semifinals. The Owls advance to Saturday's Championship, where they will face FIU. Ethan Schumaker opened the scoring on Wednesday in the 37th minute. Schumaker's shot from distance took a deflection off the back of a Tulsa defender, sending the goalkeeper in the opposite direction. The Owls doubled the lead just four minutes later. Oliver Moller-Jensen's shot from the top of the penalty area ricocheted off the post and in. The Owls went into halftime up 2-0. The Owls dug in and stifled the Tulsa attack for much of the second half. The Golden Hurricane were held without a shot on target in the final 45 minutes. Inside the final 10 minutes, it was Moller-Jensen who delivered the final blow. Played in on a breakaway by Mamadou Diarra, Moller-Jensen calmly slotted home his second goal of the night to make it 3-0 and seal the Owls' place in the Championship. you know he had to get the brace üòè üì∫| https://t.co/LHbWi8zTiy#BuiltToRise x @FAUMSoccer pic.twitter.com/4KRhaDUPWL ‚Äî The American (@American_Conf) November 12, 2025 Goalkeeper Alfred Mikkelsen returned from a four-game absence to earn his sixth solo clean sheet of the season. Mikkelsen needed to make just one save. The Owls will now look to earn the second conference tournament title in program history. Saturday's Championship kicks off at 6 p.m. For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Earn Midweek Sweep Over Bulls
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic volleyball team earned a gritty straight-set sweep over the South Florida Bulls, 3-0 (25-21, 25-20, 25-20), on Wednesday inside the Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls improve to 18-10 overall and 9-6 in American play, but the Bulls fall to 15-11 on the season and 11-4 in conference play. HOW IT HAPPENED South Florida led early, opening the match on a 6-3 run, but the Owls responded with a 7-1 run of their own, capped off by a Kierstin Bevelle kill and a pair of Bulls' errors to give the Owls a three-point advantage at 10-7 and force a USF timeout. The Bulls tied the score at 15 and 16, however, the Owls scored three unanswered points off a kill from Maggie Allred and back-to-back USF errors to extend their lead back to three, 19-16. The Bulls cut the Owls' lead to just two at 23-21, but a kill from Kayla Richardson and an ace from Emsley Venard closed out the opening frame as the Owls took the 25-21 win. The Owls struck first in the second, but the Bulls opened the set on a 6-4 run. The Owls answered back as back-to-back Victoria Hensley aces capped off a 6-0 run to make it 10-6 and spark a USF timeout. The Bulls cut the Owls' lead to just one at 17-16 to force an FAU timeout, but the Owls locked in, closing the second set on an 8-4 run to win the set, 25-20, and take the two-set lead. South Florida once again took a lead in the third, opening the set on a 10-6 run. However, the Owls continued to flex their muscles, scoring seven unanswered points off kills from Libby Ashline and Olivia Hart and numerous USF errors to take a three-point lead at 13-10. The Bulls tied things back up, but after a 17-17 stalemate, the Owls kept firing on all cylinders, closing the match on an 8-3 run to clinch the straight-set sweep, 25-20. STATS & NOTES Hart and Ashline led the Owls offensively. Hart posted a team-leading eight kills, while Ashline tallied seven kills on a team-high .385 hitting performance in the win. Ashline also led the Owls at the net, recording a match-high five blocks. Hensley led the team in assists, dishing out a team-leading 14. Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, finishing with a team-best 10 digs. The Owls capitalized on numerous Bulls' hitting errors, forcing 26 USF attack errors, and dominated at the service line, outpacing the Bulls in aces, 7-0. FAU also held an advantage in blocks, 9-8. UP NEXT The Owls close out the regular season on Friday, Nov. 14, hosting the UTSA Roadrunners for Senior Day. First serve is scheduled for 6 p.m. inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Fall at Miami
content: CORAL GABLES, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team fell in a hard-fought game 79-47 against the Miami Hurricanes on Thursday evening at the Watsco Center. The Owls move to 2-1 on the season, and the Hurricanes improve to 3-0. HOW IT HAPPENED Miami jumped to a 9-0 lead, holding Florida Atlantic scoreless for over three minutes in the first quarter. Ineivi Plata was able to put the Owls on the board with a layup, making the score 9-2. FAU was unable to close the gap throughout the first quarter, ending the period down 24-9. Jess Moors opened the scoring for Florida Atlantic in the second. Moor's points were followed by two Haley Walker layups and a Madi Gewirtz 3-pointer to cut Miami's lead to 11 with a score of 29-18. From there, the Hurricanes began to pull away, going on a 5-0 run. Michiyah Simmons stopped that run with her first points of the game late in the second quarter. The first half ended with the Hurricanes leading 42-23. Miami extended its lead to 23 at the beginning of the third quarter. Vivian Onugha stifled the Hurricane run with her first of the game to put the Owls back on the board, 46-25. Plata led Florida Atlantic in scoring in the third quarter with four points. Miami held a 26-point lead with the score standing at 61-35 going into the fourth quarter. The Owls scored first in the fourth from a Walker layup, 61-37. Grace Carstensen had her ninth point of the night shortly after knocking down her third 3-pointer. Miami slowly pulled away, extending its lead to 32 with four minutes to go. The Owls battled through the end of the fourth, ultimately ending the game 79-47. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I thought we competed really well, but unfortunately, we didn't have our legs under us. The physicality of Miami's team kind of wore us down early. We had some open looks that typically fall for us, and they just weren't falling, and against a team like Miami, you really need those shots to fall. Proud of our effort, and I know we can learn a lot from this game." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Carstensen led the Owls with a team-high 14 points on the night. Gewirtz led the team on the glass with four boards. Moors had a team-leading three assists. The Owls led the Hurricanes at the line with 58 percent to 50 percent. Florida Atlantic led Miami in steals, 10-6. GALLERY Gallery: (11-13-2025) Florida Atlantic WBB at Miami (Nov. 13) UP NEXT The Owls will finish their three-game road trip in Mobile, Alabama, where they will face South Alabama on Thursday, Nov. 20, at 7 p.m. at the Mitchell Center on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

headline: Owls Set to Travel to Alabama for Regionals
content: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's men's and women's cross country teams will travel to Huntsville for the 2025 NCAA Regionals on Friday, Nov.14 to conclude the 2025 fall season. The Owls are set to compete in the NCAA South Regionals, with the races airing on ESPN+. The women will run the 6K at 9:30 a.m., while the men will take on a 10K run beginning at 10:30 a.m. Florida Atlantic will compete at John Hunt Park. On the women's side, Reese Anderson, Madison Brown, Sophie Dethier, Leah Helms, Morgan Pennington, Anabell Reumann, Rosa ten Berg, and Elyssa Toal will compete in the 6k for the Owls. On the men's side, Nazayer Franco, Paul Glick, Samuel Henery, Noah Highsmith, Donovan Petty, and Nathan Webb will run the 10k. LAST TIME OUT Women (2025 American Championships) ten Berg finished with a time of 22:08.1 as the top Owl finisher for the second consecutive meet. Toal came in second for the Owls as she placed 53rd overall on the course with a time of 22:17.6. Seconds behind was Brown, running a 22:28.4. Reumann finished 64th overall with a 22:42.1. Helms finished 68th overall (22:52.4). Dethier (22:59.0) and Anderson (23:45.7) finished 70th and 81st overall in their first postseason run with the Owls. Men (2025 American Championships) As a team, Florida Atlantic recorded 360 points. Glick got it started for the Owls when he was the first to cross the finish line. Right behind was the freshman Petty with a time of 26:36.8. He recorded a career-best at the American Championships; last year. Back-to-back were Franco and Highsmith in their first appearance in an American Championship Webb placed 90th overall in his first postseason appearance. SEASON HIGHLIGHTS The Owls started off the season at the Keiser Invitational. Brown, Dethier, Anderson, and Pennington made their debut as Owls. On the men's side, Henery has competed very well in every race he has made an appearance. Webb, Franco, and Highsmith competed for the first time in an FAU uniform. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage of FAU cross country and track & field, follow us on social media. (@FAUXCTF)

headline: 2025 NFL Owls
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Week 10 of the 2025 NFL season is in the books with five former Florida Atlantic Owls seeing action. Here's a rundown of how each performed during the 10th week (All gametimes listed below are Eastern): Active Owls (5) #0 Azeez Al-Shaair | LB | Houston Texans - For the fourth consecutive game, Al-Shaair played 100% of the team's defensive snaps. He notched a team-leading eight tackles and added a pass breakup in Houston's 36-29 comeback win over the Jacksonville Jaguars. Texans' Record: 4-5 Next Game: at Tennessee ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) #88 Harrison Bryant | TE | Houston Texans - Bryant served as Houston's starting tight end in their major fourth quarter comeback victory. He saw the field for 17 snaps on offense and four on special teams in the 36-29 win. Texans' Record: 4-5 Next Game: at Tennessee ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) #84 Zaire Mitchell-Paden | TE | New Orleans Saints - Mitchell-Paden played a career high 26 snaps in New Orleans' 17-7 win over their NFC South rival Carolina Panthers. He logged his longest catch with a 14-yard grab with a first down. Saints' Record: 2-8 Next Game: The Saints will have their bye weekend before returning on Sunday, Nov. 23 to face the Atlanta Falcons. #42 James Pierre | CB | Pittsburgh Steelers - Pierre stepped up in a primetime performance against the Los Angeles Chargers on Sunday night football. In 48 snaps, he made five tackles and two key pass deflections. Pittsburgh ultimately fell to L.A. by a score of 25-10. Steelers' Record: 5-4 Next Game: vs. Cincinnati (and Hendrickson) ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (CBS) #26 Devin Singletary | RB | New York Giants - "Motor" made the longest play of the day for New York. On a third-and-one, he caught a pass behind the line of scrimmage and turned a potential tackle-for-loss into a 41-yard gain down the sideline to set up a Giants score. Singletary finished with 20 yards on eight rushes and 53 on three receptions as New York was defeated by the Chicago Bears in a 24-20 last-minute loss. Giants' Record: 2-8 Next Game: vs. Green Bay ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) On a Bye (1) #91 Trey Hendrickson | DE | Cincinnati Bengals Bengals' Record: 3-6 Next Game: at Pittsburgh (and Pierre) ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (CBS) Practice Squad (4) #58 Evan Anderson | DT | San Francisco 49ers #34 Greg Joseph | K | Las Vegas Raiders #62 Federico Maranges | C | Seattle Seahawks #73 Brandon Walton | OT | Carolina Panthers Check fausports.com each Thursday to see how each Owl did the previous week along with a preview of their respective team's next game.

headline: Hometown Team with Leila Etemadi
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. -- In an effort to make the Owls the hometown team for Boca Raton, student-athletes have totaled nearly 20,000 hours of community service during Vice President and Director of Athletics Brian White's tenure. In part of this effort, we will showcase our hometown student-athletes from the Florida Keys through West Palm Beach. Meet Florida Atlantic's women's soccer senior, Leila Etemadi, as one of our Hometown student-athletes of the "Hometown Team" series. MEET LEILA ETEMADI Hometown Team is presented by Wyndham Deerfield Beach Resort. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things Florida Atlantic women's soccer, follow FAU on social media @FAUWSoccer.

headline: Pads Off with Vincent Fiacable
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's Inside the Owls' Burrow television show, which airs each week on FanDuel Sports Network Florida, will highlight Vincent Fiacable in this week's show. Fiacable, who hails from Fort Wayne, Indiana, transferred to the Owls in the summer of 2025. Since that time, he has shifted from guard to center as has served as the team's starting center since the first snap of 2025 at Maryland. The redshirt junior is the only Owl offensive lineman that started each of the team's nine games at the same position. PADS OFF To follow the games: football is scheduled to play at Tulane at 4 p.m. ET on Saturday, Nov. 15. The game will air on ESPN+ air on Fox Sports 640 AM South Florida. CELEBRATING 25 YEARS Click HERE for 25 Years Celebration Content. COMPLETE 2025 SCHEDULE Click HERE. GROUPS OF ALL AGES To purchase group tickets, click HERE. FOLLOW THE TEAM Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through football's Twitter and Instagram accounts @FAUFootball.

content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer (11-3-2) knocked off Tulsa (5-9-4) by a 3-0 final on Wednesday in the American Conference Semifinals. The Owls advance to Saturday's Championship, where they will face FIU. Ethan Schumaker opened the scoring on Wednesday in the 37th minute. Schumaker's shot from distance took a deflection off the back of a Tulsa defender, sending the goalkeeper in the opposite direction. The Owls doubled the lead just four minutes later. Oliver Moller-Jensen's shot from the top of the penalty area ricocheted off the post and in. The Owls went into halftime up 2-0. The Owls dug in and stifled the Tulsa attack for much of the second half. The Golden Hurricane were held without a shot on target in the final 45 minutes. Inside the final 10 minutes, it was Moller-Jensen who delivered the final blow. Played in on a breakaway by Mamadou Diarra, Moller-Jensen calmly slotted home his second goal of the night to make it 3-0 and seal the Owls' place in the Championship. you know he had to get the brace üòè üì∫| https://t.co/LHbWi8zTiy#BuiltToRise x @FAUMSoccer pic.twitter.com/4KRhaDUPWL ‚Äî The American (@American_Conf) November 12, 2025 Goalkeeper Alfred Mikkelsen returned from a four-game absence to earn his sixth solo clean sheet of the season. Mikkelsen needed to make just one save. The Owls will now look to earn the second conference tournament title in program history. Saturday's Championship kicks off at 6 p.m. For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Travel to Coral Gables to Challenge Miami
content: Boca Raton, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team continues its road stretch on Thursday, Nov. 13, as the Owls head to Coral Gables for a battle with ACC foe Miami. Tipoff is scheduled for 7 p.m. inside the Watsco Center on ACCNX. MATCHUP INFO Florida Atlantic (2-0) at Miami (2-0) Date: Thursday, Nov. 13 Time: 7 p.m. ET Location: Watsco Center in Coral Gables, Fla. GAME COVERAGE TV: ACCNX Live Stats: StatBroadcast A LOOK AT THE OWLS The Florida Atlantic Owls enter Thursday's midweek matchup 2-0 after earning a pair of season-opening wins over Florida Memorial, 89-46, and Kennesaw State, 69-68. The Owls are led offensively by Vivian Onugha, Grace Carstensen, Destyne Jackson, and Michiyah Simmons. Onugha leads the Owls, averaging 15.0 points per game. Carstensen ranks second on the team, recording 14.5 points per game, while Jackson and Simmons tie for third, tallying 10.5 points apiece through two games. Simmons and Ineivi Plata are tied for a team-leading 3.5 assists per game. On the glass, the Owls are led by Haley Walker, collecting 8.0 rebounds per contest, and Onugha, who ranks second on the team with 7.5 boards per game so far this season. The Owls' steals leader is Jackson, tallying 1.5 steals per game. SCOUTING MIAMI Miami enters Wednesday's contest at 2-0 after opening the season with wins over Hofstra, 83-48, and Bethune-Cookman, 74-41. The Canes are led offensively by Ra Shaya Kyle and Ahnay Adams. Kyle boasts a team-leading 16 points per game, while Adams is also averaging double-figures with 11 points per game. Kyle also paces the team in the glass, collecting a team-high 7.5 rebounds per game. Jessica Peterson and Candace Kpetikou rank second on the team, collecting 6.5 rebounds per game, each. Gal Raviv is the Canes' assists leader, dishing out a team-high 5.5 assists per game this season. Kyle, Peterson, and Natalie Wetzel are tied for the team lead in blocks, recording two blocks apiece. SERIES HISTORY Wednesday's meeting marks the 21st all-time meeting between Florida Atlantic and Miami. The Owls will look for their first win over the Canes. Miami has won 16 contests in Coral Gables, including a 75-42 win in the last meeting between the two programs on Nov. 16, 2022. LAST TIME OUT: AT KENNESAW STATE The Owls extended their season-opening winning streak to 2-0 with a 69-68 road win at Kennesaw State on Saturday. Four Florida Atlantic players finished in double figures. Jackson with 13, Simmons with 12, Jess Moors with 11, and Carstensen with 10. Vivian Onugha led the team in rebounds on the night with four. Simmons had a team-leading five assists. The Owls were 50 percent from both field goal and 3-point range on the night, matching up well to Kennesaw State's 48.1 field goal percentage and 16.7 three-point percentage. UP NEXT Following Wednesday's contest, the Owls will head to Mobile, Alabama, to close out their three-game road trip, visiting South Alabama on Thursday, Nov. 20, for an 8 p.m. tipoff on ESPN+ at the Mitchell Center. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.
